Transition-metal incorporated heteropolyacid-ionic liquid composite catalysts with tunable Brønsted/Lewis acidity for acetalization of benzaldehyde with ethylene glycol Xiaoxiang Han a ⁎ Kai Ouyang a Chunhua Xiong a Xiujuan Tang b Qing Chen a Kuiwu Wang a Li-Li Liu c Chin-Te Hung c Shang-Bin Liu c ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, Zhejiang Gongshang University, Hangzhou, 310018, China Department of Applied Chemistry Zhejiang Gongshang University Hangzhou 310018 China b College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Zhejiang Gongshang University, Hangzhou, 310018, China College of Environmental Science and Engineering Zhejiang Gongshang University Hangzhou 310018 China c Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences, Academia Sinica, Taipei 10617, Taiwan, Taiwan Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences Academia Sinica Taipei 10617 Taiwan ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A water-soluble Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst with extraordinary catalytic activity, excellent durability, strong Brønsted/Lewis acidity, and unique self-separation property during acetalization of benzaldehyde with ethylene glycol is reported. A series of transition-metal (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) ion-exchanged tungstophosphoric acid (H3PW12O40; TPA)-based ionic liquid (IL) catalysts, synthesized by incorporating metal and methylimidazolium propyl sulfobetaine (MIMPS) zwitterionic IL precursors onto TPA, were exploited for acetalization of benzaldehyde (BzH) with ethylene glycol (EG). These organic-inorganic, water-soluble M-MIMPS-TPA composite salts possess not only strong Brønsted and Lewis acidities but also exhibited unique self-separation property desirable for catalyst separation and recycling. The superior acetalization activities observed for these novel M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts are attributed to their strong acidity, Brønsted/Lewis acid synergy, and low mass transport resistance. Among them, the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst showed extraordinary catalytic performance and durability with a benzaldehyde glycol acetal selectivity and yield of 99.0 and 94.6%, respectively, in excellent agreement with results from response surface methodology. Further kinetic study gave rise to an activation energy of 34.11kJ/mol for the acetalization reaction, surpassing most reported catalysts. Keywords Ionic liquid Heteropolyacid Acetalization Acidity Process optimization 1 Introduction The formation of cyclic acetals by acetalization of ethylene glycol (EG) plays a key role in multi-step organic synthesis [1–3]. Cyclic acetals, which are known to be resistant against various nucleophiles, basic, and oxidizing reagents, are commonly used for blocking the carbonyl functional groups during preparative, organic chemistry. Moreover, acetals show many unique properties desirable for practical industrial applications either as solvents, intermediates, polymers, fragrances/flavors, or biofuels [4–6]. Conventionally, production of acetals (or ketals) invokes homogeneous catalysis using mineral acid catalysts such as H2SO4, HCl, and H3PO4, which are drawback by poor product selectivity, environmental hazards, equipment corrosion, and catalyst disposal/recycling issues, hence, nonconformity with sustainable developments. To avoid these problems, heterogeneous catalysts such as supported Lewis acid [7–9], resins [10–12], and zeolites [13,14] have been employed to catalyze the acetalization reaction. Nevertheless, these solid acid catalysts show only limited applications due to low activity, vulnerable to deactivation, and formidable separation and recycling procedures and so on. Thus, the development of highly efficient homogeneous/heterogeneous acid catalysts with environmental benignity would be highly desirable for the production of acetals. To this regard, heteropolyacids (HPAs), which exhibit strong acidity, unique redox and pseudoliquid properties [15,16], have shown prospective potentials in replacing the conventional acid catalysts [17–19]. Consequently, HPAs and their derivatives have been widely exploited as homogeneous and/or heterogeneous catalysts for productions of fine/special chemicals. Notwithstanding, their catalytic applications are still limited by low thermal stability, low surface area, and inferior solubility in polar solvents [15–20]. To circumvent these issues, some earlier research studies made use of porous materials supported HPA catalysts, which readily improved the thermal stability and facilitated product separation procedure of the heterogeneous reaction system [21,22]. However, such supported HPA catalysts were found to be hampered by other issues such as mass transfer resistance and leaching, especially for those prepared by physisorption techniques. As such, research and developments on highly active and durable HPA-based catalysts with facile recovery and recycling remain a challenging and demanding tasks. Meanwhile, an increasing R&D attention has been focused on ionic liquid (IL)-based catalysts. ILs are known as green designer solvents [23–27] owing to their unique properties such as negligible volatility，excellent solvating ability, good thermal stability, and potential recyclability [28–30]. Moreover, ILs are hybrid materials consist of a cationic and an anionic components that may be easily synthesized with a wide variety of organic/inorganic chemicals. For examples, by incorporating HPAs onto ILs, the organic-inorganic composite catalysts were found to exhibit strong acidity, excellent catalytic activity, enhanced thermal stability, rapid mass transfer, and solvent-responsive properties desirable for both heterogeneous and homogeneous reactions [31–36]. For examples, by immobilizing tungstophosphoric acid (TPA; H3PW12O40) on a pyridinium propyl sulfobetaine (PPS) IL, we succeeded in preparing a series of [PPSH] x H 3−x PW12O40 (x =1.0–3.0) composite catalysts, which exhibited extremely high activity for acetalization of benzaldehyde (BzH) with EG [34] as well as acetylation of glycerol with acetic acid [35], resulting in an excellent benzaldehyde ethylene glycol acetal (BEGA) and glycerol triacetate (GTA) yield exceeding 85 and 90%, respectively. The high activities observed for both reactions were attributed to the strong Brønsted acid sites possessed by the PPS-TPA composite catalysts. By incorporating nickel (Ni) metal center onto TPA, Liu and co-workers demonstrated [37] that the Ni1.5PW12O40 catalyst, which possessed strong Lewis acidity, also showed good catalytic activity for acetalization of BzH with EG with an acetal (BEGA) yield of 81.6%. In addition, by introducing Lewis metal center onto the Brønsted acidic ILs, catalytic conversions of biomass invoking a Brønsted-Lewis acid synergy were also revealed by both experimental and theoretical studies [28,36,37,38]. We report herein, an alternative synthesis route for the direct preparation of a new series of TPA-base composite catalysts that possess both Brønsted and Lewis acid centers by incorporating TPA with varied amounts of transition-metal (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu; as Lewis acid centers) and methylimidazolium propyl sulfobetaine (MIMPS) zwitterionic IL precursors. The physicochemical properties of the as-synthesized M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts were characterized by a variety of different analytical and spectroscopic techniques such as FT-IR, XPS, XRD, and TGA. In particular, their acidic properties were probed by solid-state 31P MAS NMR of adsorbed trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) as the probe molecule, namely the 31P-TMPO NMR approach for acidity characterization [28,33–35,39,40]. Moreover, their catalytic performances were investigated by acetalization of benzaldehyde (BzH) with ethylene glycol (EG) and the corresponding reaction process and product yield were optimized by a factorial experimental design and response surface methodology (RSM) [41,42]. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation All the chemicals were analytical reagents and were used without further purification unless specified otherwise. The M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) were prepared directly by mixing desirable amounts of calcined tungstophosphoric acid (H3PW12O40; TPA) and methylimidazolium propyl sulfobetaine (MIMPS) IL with known amounts of desirable metal nitrate precursors, namely Mn(NO3)2·6H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O [32,43]. In brief, the mixture solution was placed in a three-neck flask and allowed to keep at 363K for 24h under continuous stirring condition. Upon water removal, the obtained solid product was washed with diethyl ether followed by drying under vacuum. For comparison purpose, MIMPS-TPA exchanged with transition-metal cation (M+n =Mn+2, Fe+3, Co+2, Cu+2; n =2 or 3), namely M2/n [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x = y =1.0), were prepared together with a series of Ni2+-exchanged Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2) composite catalysts, as listed in Table 1 . All reported data in Table 1 were average results from three parallel runs. The conversion and selectivity data were obtained from GC analyses, whereas the acetal yields were deduced from distillation analyses. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were acquired on a Bruker IFS-28 spectrometer using anhydrous KBr as the standard. Each spectrum was recorded over the range of 4000–400cm−1 with a resolution of 1cm−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were performed on an ESCALab220i-XL spectrometer (VG Scientific) operating at 300W using a monochromatized Al Kα (1486.6eV) radiation source. All powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted on a DX-2700 diffractometer (Dandong Kemait NDT Co.) using Cu Kα radiation (0.15418nm) at 40kV and 30mA. Each XRD profile was scanned over a 2θ angle of 5–80° with an interval of 0.04°. Thermogravimetric and differential thermogravimetric (TG-DTG) analyses were conducted on a TGA/DSC-1 (Mettler Toledo) thermal analyzer. Typically, each sample was heated from room temperature (RT; 298K) to 873K at a heating rate of 10K/min under a dynamic N2 atmosphere. Elemental analyses (EA) were carried out on an iCAP 6500 ICP-OES analyzer (Thermo Scientific) equipped with a unique charge injection device (CID) detector. Solid-state 31P magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) experiments were performed on a Bruker-Biospin AVANCE III 500 spectrometer operating at 202.46MHz. All spectra were recorded using a single pulse sequence under the following conditions: pulse-width, 1.5μs (π/6); recycle delay, 10s; sample spinning rate, 12kHz. All 31P NMR chemical shift (δ31P) were referenced to 85% H3PO4 aqueous solution (as 0ppm). Detailed sample preparation procedures invoked for acidity characterization using trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) as the probe molecule (i.e., the 31P-TMPO NMR approach) can be found elsewhere [28,34,35,39]. 2.3 Acetalization reaction The catalytic performances for various catalysts were assessed by acetalization of ethylene glycol (EG) with benzaldehyde (BzH), as illustrated in Scheme 1 . In a typical experiment, known amounts of EG (9.3g, 0.15mol) and BzH (10.6g, 0.1mol) were mixed with 5wt% of a desirable catalyst (0.53g) together with the water-carrying agent (i.e., cyclohexane, 12mL) in a 100mL three-necked flask. The reaction time was recorded when reaching a desirable reflux temperature. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was cooled to RT. Owing to the self-separation characteristics of the reaction system, which formed biphasic layers after the reaction. The upper organic liquid layer containing products and reactants was first washed with half-saturated brine twice, then, distilled by using an air condenser to collect products in the boiling point range of 497−503K. It is noteworthy that the primary product, namely benzaldehyde ethylene glycol acetal (BEGA), is colorless. Chemical analyses of products/reactants were carried out using gas chromatography (GC; Agilent 7890B) equipped with a FID detector and HP-5 capillary column. All products and reactants were identified by comparing with authentic samples while using biphenyl as the internal standard. The reliability of GC results were checked by distillation analysis of the acetal yield within a specific temperature range of ca. 497–503K from the products. Meanwhile, the catalyst in the lower layer was separated, followed by filtering and washing (with diethyl ether), then kept for future recycling use. 2.4 Experimental design and mathematical model Response surface methodology (RSM), which compiles both statistical and mathematical methods, has been widely used for modeling and analyzing engineering problems [41,42]. The present work aims to investigate the effects of reactant ratio, reaction time, and amounts of catalyst and water-carrying agent on acetal product yield by means of the RSM based on an experimental Box–Behnken design (BBD). Accordingly, four independent process variables, namely ethylene glycol/benzaldehyde molar ratio (x 1), reaction time (x 2), amount of catalyst (x 3), and amount of water-carrying agent (x 4; i.e., amount of cyclohexane), were chosen at three coded levels of experimental design with designated range, as depicted in Table 2 . Accordingly, a 34 full-factorial experimental BBD with coded levels were exploited, leading to a total of 29 experimental sets, including 24 factorial points and 5 centering points (Table 3 ). The aforementioned levels in Table 2 were coded with either a plus sign (+1; higher value), zero (0; central value), or a minus sign (−1; lower value) whose values were defined by: (1) x i = X i − X 0 Δ X i where xi (i =1−4) represents the coded value of each independent variable, and Xi and X 0 are the real and central values of the independent variable, respectively, whilst ΔXi =(variable at high level − variable at low level)/2 denotes the corresponding step change value. Moreover, a second-order model equation given by RSM was used to reveal the interactive effects between experimental variables, to optimize the reaction process, and to predict the response (Y) of the experimental design, namely the yield of acetal product (i.e., benzaldehyde ethylene glycol acetal; BEGA). The quadratic model equation may be expressed as [41,42]: (2) Y = β 0 + ∑ i = 1 3 β i x i + ∑ i = 1 3 β i i x i 2 + ∑ i < j 3 β i j x i x j where Y is the predicted response, xi and xj are the coded levels of the independent variables, and β0 , βi , βii , and βij , represent the regression coefficients of the offset, linear, quadratic, and interaction terms, respectively. Accordingly, the fitted polynomial equation may further be expressed by means of response surface and contour plots to visualize correlations between the response and experimental variables at different coded levels and to infer optimized process conditions. Moreover, the coefficient of determination (R2 ) obtained from the fitting may be used to assess the accuracy and validity of the second order multiple regression model. The significance of its regression coefficient may also be checked by the value of F-test. 2.5 Kinetic study A kinetic study during acetalization of BzH with EG over the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst was carried out using a set of variables obtained from the multi-objective optimization. The reaction rate (r) for the acetalization reaction may be described as: (3) r = − d C A d t = k + C A α C B β − k − C C γ C D η where CA , CB , CC , and CD denote the concentrations of BzH, EG, BEGA, and water, respectively, while α, β, γ, and η are their corresponding reaction order, and k+ and k− represents the rate constant associated with the forward and reverse reaction, respectively. Provided that water may be effectively removed in the presences of the water-carrying agent (i.e., cyclohexane) and excessive amount of EG reactant during acetalization reaction, the reaction may readily be considered as an irreversible process. In this context, the second terms in Eq. (3) may be obsoleted, and the rate equation may be rewritten as: (4) r = − d C A d t = k + C A α C B β For simplicity, assuming that the forward and reverse reaction are both first-order (α= β =1), the values of the modified rate constant k for the acetalization reaction at different temperatures may therefore be determined by the linear fitting of the ln(CA/CB ) vs t curve defined as: (5) ln C A C B = ( C A O − C B O ) k t + C where CAO and CBO refers to the difference between the initial concentration of BzH and EG, respectively. The above equation may be used to derive yield of acetal (Y) as: (6) Y = 1 ( C A O − C B O ) ln C A C B = k t + C As such, the corresponding k and C values at different temperatures may be obtained by linear fitting of Eq. (6) using the Origin 8.5 software. Accordingly, the variation of reaction rate with temperature may be expressed by the Arrhenius equation: (7) ln k = ln k 0 − E a R 1 T where R is the gas constant and T denotes the reaction temperature. Thus, the activation energy (Ea ) and the pre-exponential factor (k 0) may be derived from the Arrhenius (ln k vs 1/T) plot. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The structural compositions of various catalysts were confirmed by FT-IR studies. As shown in Figs. S1 and S2 of the Supplementary Information (hereafter denoted as SI). All Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2) composite catalysts exhibited the presences of four vibrational bands at 1078, 981, 896, and 806cm−1 similar to that of pristine TPA (Fig. S2a; SI). These bands are typical characteristics of a Keggin-type structure [31–34,44–46]. The vibrational bands observed for Ni2+-promoted MIMPS-TPA catalysts at 1050−1100 and 970−1000cm−1 may be assigned due to POa and WOd stretching vibrations associated with the central (Oa) and terminal (Od) oxygens, whose positions remained practically unchanged with the amount of incorporated Ni. This indicates the retention of Keggin structure in TPA even after the incorporation of Ni and MIMPS [47]. As for the asymmetric WOcW vibrations at ca. 806cm−1, the band broadened with increasing loading of Ni, whilst new bands in the 650−600cm−1 region were found, indicating coupling between the W and [MIMPS]/Ni [48]. Moreover, the band at 420cm−1 should be assigned to WONi stretching rather than NiO vibrations [49,50]. The above results indicate the retention of the Keggin structure even though partial destruction of the Keggin unit may also took place. Whereas, the broad band near 3429cm−1 may be attributed to OH, SO3H, and NH stretching vibrations, which becoming more pronounced upon incorporating Ni2+ onto the MIMPS-TPA. On the other hand, the bands at 1578 and 1450cm−1 observed for the Ni-MIMPS-TPAs (Figs. S1b−i; SI) are ascribed to CN and CH2 stretching vibrations, whilst bands at 1222 and 1170cm−1 due to SO stretching vibrations, which verified the presence of sulfonic groups in the catalysts. Moreover, all M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts also exhibited additional band at 634cm−1, which corresponds to the bending CH vibrations in the imidazole fragment [33]. The above results obtained from FT-IR studies clearly indicate the successful linkage among the promoted metal (Ni2+), sulfonate functionalized organic cations (MIMPSH) n +; n =1−3), and the inorganic PW12O40 3− (PW) polyanions. The surface properties of the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst, which showed the best catalytic performance (vide infra), were probed by XPS technique. As revealed by the survey spectrum in Fig. 1 a, the concurring presences of key elements, viz. Ni, O, N, C, P, and W, are affirmative. The absorption signals at ca. 856.0 and 401.9eV may be ascribed due to Ni 2p and N 1s core-levels of NiO and the imidazole ring, respectively, confirming the successful incorporation of Ni and MIMPS onto the TPA [51]. In addition, the W 4f core-level XPS spectrum (Fig. 1b) showed a well-resolved doublet with binding energies of 36.1 and 38.2eV, corresponding to the W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2 spin-orbit, respectively, which are separated by 2.1eV, indicating the presence of W6+ [52]. It is noteworthy that the W 4f XPS core-level spectrum of the pristine TPA revealed a spin-orbit doublet at 35.8 (W 4f7/2) and 37.9 (W 4f5/2) eV [53]. By comparison, the higher binding energies observed for the W 4f core-levels of the Ni-MIMPS-TPA may be attributed to conversion of WO to weaker WONi bonds upon incorporating Ni metal species and the MIMPS IL. On the other hand, the P 2p XPS spectrum showed a single broad peak centering at 135.5eV (Fig. 1c), which shifted toward a lower binding energy by 0.5eV compared to that of pristine TPA (136.0eV) due to changes in chemical environments, verifying the bonding of TPA with Ni and MIMPS. Likewise, the C 1s XPS spectrum (Fig. 1d) exhibited a broad overlapping signal, which may be deconvoluted into three bands with binding energy of 286.9, 286.0, and 284.6eV, corresponding to the presences of CN, CS, and CC bonds, respectively [51,54]. The above results indicate that the Keggin structure of TPA remain intact even after modification by the organic MIMPS IL and incorporation of Ni metal. Similar conclusions may also be drawn from the XRD results, as illustrated for the pristine TPA and Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2) series samples in Fig. S3 (SI). As shown in Fig. S3a, the pristine TPA revealed three primary diffraction peaks at 10.3, 25.3, and 34.6° accountable for the secondary structure of TPA, which is formed by body centered cubic (bcc) packing of the primary structure, namely the PW polyanions [45]. Upon incorporating the MIMPS IL onto TPA (Figs. S3b,c; SI), additional diffraction peaks in the 2θ region of ca. 5–10° were observed, indicating the formation of MIMPS-TPA salt with good crystallinity. On the other hand, the sole incorporation of metallic Ni onto TPA led to notable changes in diffraction patterns, including broadening and shift of diffraction peaks, which were also accompanied by progressive decreases in peak intensities with increasing Ni loading (Figs. S3d–f; SI). This indicates severe distortion of the Keggin structure when in the sole presence of Ni species. Nevertheless, the characteristic peaks responsible for the Keggin units remained visible in the Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3-2x-y)PW12O40 catalysts after incorporating MIMPS IL and metal species onto TPA (Figs. S3g–I; SI). Thus, results obtained from XRD studies provide additional supports to the aforediscussed FT-IR and XPS data, which confirmed the successful incorporation of Ni and MIMPS IL onto the TPA without significant change in Keggin structure nor much loss in crystallinity [55]. The thermal stability of such metal-incorporated organic-inorganic MIMPS-TPA salts were further verified by TG-DTG measurements. Since all Ni x [MIM-PSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2) showed similar TG-DTG profiles within the temperature range of 298 (RT) to 873K, herein, only assorted results obtained from the pristine TPA (H3PW12O40), [MIMPSH]H2PW12O40, and Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 samples are illustrated and discussed. As shown in Fig. S4a (SI), the pristine TPA showed multiple weight-loss peaks at 339, 458, 666 and 787K. The former two peaks may be ascribed due to desorption of physisorbed water and loss of crystalline water, respectively. Whilst, the latter two weight-losses at 666 and 787K should be associated with collapses of Keggin structure [31,45]. By comparison, four distinct weight-losses were observed for the [MIMPSH]H2PW12O40 sample (Fig. S4b; SI). Again, the peaks occurred in the temperature range of 303–385 and 448K should be due to desorption of surface-bound and crystalline water, respectively. Whereas, the peak at 569K should be associated with decomposition of the organic moieties (from the MIMPS IL) and the broad feature at ca. 688K due to collapse of Keggin structure. On the other hand, only two major weight-loss peaks were observed for the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst (Fig. S4c; SI). The peak appeared at 323−493K may be attributed unambiguously to the loss of physisorbed and crystalline water, while the peak at 717K should be due to decomposition of organic species in the Ni-MIMPS-TPA catalyst. Thus, the above results further demonstrated that the PW polyanions were indeed successfully anchored with Ni2+ and [MIMPSH]+ cations, and remained stable at temperatures employed during catalytic reaction studies (<400K). For the acid-catalyzed reaction, the acid features, namely the types (Brønsted vs Lewis acid), concentration (i.e., acid amount), location, and strength of acid sites, play the key roles in dictating the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Solid-state 31P MAS NMR of adsorbed trimethylphosphine oxide (TMPO) probe molecule, has been shown to be a powerful technique for acidity characterization of solid acids [39,40]. Such 31P-TMPO NMR approach for acidity characterization is based on the fact that, coupling of TMPO probe molecules with Brønsted acid sites tends to form TMPOH+ complexes, whose acidic strengths are linearly correlated with their corresponding 31P NMR chemical shift (δ31P) [39,40,56,57]. As demonstrated in an earlier study [45], typical 31P MAS NMR spectrum of TMPO adsorbed on pure TPA normally reveals 31P resonance signals in different δ31P regions spanned over the range from ca. −20 to 95ppm. The four different δ31P regions are: region I (80−95ppm), region II (55−80ppm), region III (30−55ppm), and region IV (−17 ∼ −10ppm). The 31P signals in the regions I and III are assigned to TMPOH+ adsorption complexes and physisorbed TMPO, respectively. Whilst, the 31P resonances in region II are attribute to (TMPO) n H+ (n ≥2) adducts, which correspond to couplings of more than one TMPO molecules with a Brønsted acid site [45]. On the other hand, the 31P signals in region IV may be ascribed unambiguously due to PW polyanions of the bare TPA. Among various 31P NMR signals observed for TMPO adsorbed on TPA, resonance peaks locate in region I with δ31P of 87.7, 89.4, and 92.1ppm were shown to arise from 1:1 TMPOH+ adsorption complex corresponding to an adsorbed probe molecule on one Brønsted acid site of the three available acidic protons (H+) locate at different terminal oxygen (Od) sites of the TPA (H3PW12O40), respectively. The fact that these three resonances all have δ31P values exceeding 86ppm provide direct support to the notion that TPA indeed possesses three superacidic acid sites with different acidic strengths [39,40,45,56,57]. On the basis of the 31P-TMPO NMR approach, the 31P spectra of TMPO adsorbed on the pristine TPA and various MIMPS-TPA and Ni-MIMPS-TPA catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2a, 31P MAS NMR spectrum of the pristine TPA showed anticipated multiple resonances in different chemical shift regions (vide supra). Again, the resonances with δ31P >86ppm (region I) are attributed to TMPO adsorbed on superacidic Brønsted acid sites of the TPA. Whereas the signals in region II (60−85ppm) are most likely due to distorted TMPOH+ and/or (TMPO)2H+ adducts. While no signals associated with physisorbed or bulk TMPO were visible, two additional peaks responsible for the Keggin PW polyanions at ca. −11 and −15ppm were observed (not shown) [45]. By comparison, though no significant changes in Brønsted acidic strength (i.e., δ31P) were observed, severe broadening of 31P resonances were evident upon introducing organic MIMPS IL onto the inorganic TPA (Fig. 2b, c). The 31P NMR spectra obtained from TMPO adsorbed on these MIMPS-TPA composites clearly differ from that of bulk MIMPS IL [34]. Likewise, severe broadening of resonance peaks were also evident upon incorporating Ni metal species onto the pristine TPA (Fig. 2d–f), which were also accompanied by notable increases in acidic strengths of the composite catalysts, which appeared to be proportional to increasing metal Ni loading. Again, the above findings provide strong supports to the notion that the PW polyanions were indeed successfully anchored with Ni2+ and [MIMPSH]+ cations, in excellent agreement with results obtained from XRD, XPS, FT-IR, and thermal analyses. On the other hand, by simultaneous incorporation of Lewis metal centers (Ni) and MIMPS IL onto TPA, notable increases in both peak intensities and δ31P of the 31P resonances of the Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3-2x-y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2) catalysts were observed, as shown in Fig. 2g−i. In addition to the peaks at 88.6 and 92.0ppm, which should be arising from TMPO adsorbed on superacidic Brønsted H+ sites, a pronounced peak at 83.5ppm was evident. This peak may be ascribed due to the presences of strong Lewis acid sites invoked by the incorporated metal Ni center [28,58]. Moreover, the acid concentrations (i.e., peak areas) appear to decrease with increasing MIMPS or Ni loading relative to TPA. Thus, in terms of overall acid strength and concentration, the following trend may be inferred: Ni0.5[MIMPSH]2PW12O40 < Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 <Ni0.5[MIMPSH]HPW12O40. It is anticipated that increasing incorporation of MIMPS and/or Ni not only facilitates elimination of available protic sites but also promotes segregation of Keggin PW units to favor fast molecular transport (vide infra) [33,59]. In this context, the transport of TMPO probe molecules in the Ni-MIMPS-TPA composite catalysts most likely invokes a desorption/absorption process associated with the (TMPO) n H+ (n ≥2) adducts. 3.2 Acetalization of aldehyde to acetal The catalytic performances of the pristine TPA and various M-MIMPS-TPA (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) catalysts for acetalization of aldehydes to acetals were assessed, as summarized in Table 1. The experimental results display in Table 1 for various catalysts were obtained under the same reaction conditions: EG/BzH=1.5mol/mol; amount of catalyst amount=5wt%; amount of water-carrying agent (cyclohexane)=12mL; reaction time=2h; reaction temperature=383K. It is clear that while majority of the catalysts exhibited desirable benzaldehyde ethylene glycol acetal (BEGA) selectivity (≥98%), partially ion-exchanged, IL-based M-MIMPS-TPA (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) catalysts showed superior catalytic performances compared to the pristine TPA (i.e., H3PW12O40), Ni-incorporated TPA, and MIMPS-TPA. In particular, the M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts showed excellent BzH conversion and acetal (BEGA) yield, mostly exceeding 90% in both cases. Among them, the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst, which gave extraordinary conversion (95.8%), selectivity (99.0%), and acetal yield (94.6%), exhibited the highest activity and the best catalytic performance. In general, Ni-incorporated TPA and MIMPS-TPA manifested better catalytic activity than the pristine TPA. The only exception was the [MIMPSH]3PW12O40 catalyst, which showed inferior conversion and acetal yield due to complete exhaustion of three acidic protons through coupling with the MIMPS IL. Since the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst has the best performance, the role of exchangeable transition-metal species (M+n =Mn+2, Fe+3, Co+2, Cu+2) on catalytic performances of M2/n [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x = y =1.0; n =2 or 3) were compared with a series of Ni2+-exchanged Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2) composite catalysts with varied Ni loading. For the M2/n [MIMPSH]PW12O40 (n =2 or 3) series samples, the catalytic activity and acetal yield clearly follow the following treand of the exchanged metal: Ni > Fe > Mn > Co > Cu (see Table 1). Whilst, the catalytic performance of the Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2) follow the decending order: Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 > Ni0.5[MIMPSH]HPW12O40 > Ni1.5PW12O40 > NiHPW12O40 >[MIMPSH]2HPW12O4 >[MIMPSH]H2PW12O40 > Ni0.5[MIMPSH]2PW12O40 > Ni0.5H2PW12O40 > H3PW12O40. It is noteworthy that the inferences of acid types and their concentrations of acid catalysts, commonly discussed in terms of Brønsted vs Lewis (B/L) acidity ratio, on catalytic activity have been discussed [60]. Based on the above results, it is indicative that the pristine H3PW12O40, which possesses only Brønsted acidity due to the sole presence of acidic H+, the amount of Lewis acidity should increase with increasing Ni2+ loading, therefore the ascending order for catalytic activity: H3PW12O40 < Ni0.5H2PW12O40 < NiHPW12O40 < Ni1.5PW12O40 (Table 1). Likewise, the same trend may be inferred for the Ni-MIMPS-TPA series catalysts with the same MIMPS loading: [MIMPSH]H2PW12O40 < Ni0.5[MIMPSH]HPW12O40 < Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40. Clearly, the presence of Lewis acidity is favorable for catalyzing the acetalization reaction. However, in view of the fact that the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst exhibited the best catalystic activity and performances even though the concentration of Lewis (and overall) acidity of the Ni-MIMPS-TPA catalysts followed the asending order: Ni0.5[MIMPSH]2PW12O40 < Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 < Ni0.5[MIMPSH]HPW12O40 (cf. Fig. 2). Thus, a delicate balance of Brønsted and Lewis acidity is preferred for acetalization reaction. In other word, the acetalization of aldehydes to acetals invokes a Brønsted-Lewis acid synergy effect. Aspects on the effect of Brønsted-Lewis acid synergy may be realized by strong ionic coupling among the inorganic metal cation (i.e., Ni2+ as Lewis metal center), organic cation (MIMPSH+), Brønsted acidic proton (H+), and the PW polyanion (PW12P40 3−) in Ni-MIMPS-TPA composite catalysts [61]. A possible reaction mechanism invoked for acetalization of BzH over the partially Ni2+ cation-exchanged MIMPS-TPA composite catalyst, namely Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2), is displayed in Scheme 2 . Accordingly, the co-participation of Brønsted and Lewis acidity is illustrated based on the aforediscussed characterization results as well as catalytic studies. In brief, the Lewis metal center (Ni2+) tends to incorporate with the oxygen atom in the carbonyl groups (which possessed strong electronegativity) to induce interactions between the carbon atom in the carbonyl group and the oxygen in the alcohol hydroxyl group. The coupling of Brønsted acidic H+ with the oxygen atom in the carbonyl group tends to lower the negative charge, which in turn, favorable for the release of Ni2+. The intermediate formed via coupling between carbocation and oxygen in the alcohol hydroxyl group then release proton (H+) to obtain the final product. In addition to the effect of Brønsted-Lewis acid synergy, strong acidity and low transport resistance invoking the pseudoliquid characteristic of Keggin structured TPA are also responsible for the excellent catalytic activity observed during the acetalization over the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst. Meanwhile, the catalytic performance of the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst was only compared with other water-soluble IL-based TPA, namely Ni-incorporated pyridinium propyl sulfobetaine (PPS)-TPA (denoted as Ni[PPSH]PW12O40 in Table 1) catalyst. It has been shown that, in the absence of metal, the [PPSH]2HPW12O40 catalyst achieved fairly good catalytic activity with an BEGA yield over 85% [34]. The superior acetalization activity was attributed to its self-separation property, highly acidic nature, and weak mass transport resistance. Clearly, upon incorporating Ni2+, the Ni[PPSH]PW12O40 catalyst showed even higher activity with a BEGA yield of 92.4% (Table 1). Nonetheless, it is clear that the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst reported herein still outperformed the Ni[PPSH]PW12O40. 3.3 Effects of reaction parameters Since the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst was found to exhibit the best catalytic performance among various M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts (cf. Table 1), it was chosen for further process optimization study. The effects of independent experimental variables, such as alcohol to aldehyde (EG/BzH) molar ratio, reaction time, amount of catalyst, and amount of water carrying agent (i.e., cyclohexane) were investigated, as displayed in Fig. 3 . Since acetalization is a reversible reaction, thus, it is a common practice to carry out the reaction under excessive alcohol condition in order to improve the acetal yield [34]. In this work, an excessive amount of EG was always introduced over BzH to warrant catalyst solubility during the reaction. Fig. 3a shows the variations of acetal (BEGA) yield on EG/BzH molar ratio over the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst while keeping the other reaction variables fixed, viz. amount of catalyst=5wt%, reaction time=2.0h, amount of cyclohexane=12mL, and reaction temperature=383K. Clearly, the acetal yield first increased with increasing EG/BzH ratio, reaching a maximum at 1.5:1mol/mol, then gradually decreased afterward. This indicates that, a desirable amount of EG over BzH was favorable for shifting the equilibrium towards formation of acetal, as expected. However, surplus amount of EG may over dilute the reactant, leading to an inferior acetal yield. The influence of reaction time on catalytic activity was investigated under the experimental conditions: EG/BzH=1.5mol/mol, amount of catalyst=5wt%, amount of cyclohexane=12mL, and reaction temperature=383K. As shown in Fig. 3b, the acetal yield increased progressively with reaction time, resulting a maximum yield of 94.6% at reaction time of ca. 2h. However, the acetal yield decreased notably at prolonged reaction time. This reflects that acetalization is indeed an equilibrium reaction and that hemiacetal and/or acetal products may react with water formed during the reaction to spoil the selectivity and yield of BEGA product at prolonged reaction time (>2h). Thus, in views of production cost and energy consumption, a reaction time of 2h seems desirable for acetalization of BzH with EG to BEGA. The role of catalyst amount during the acetalization reaction was also investigated and the results are displayed in Fig. 3c. In this case, the reactions were carried out by varying the catalyst amount from 3 to 7wt%, while kipping other reaction parameters fixed: EG/BzH=1.5mol/mol, reaction time=2.0h, amount of cyclohexane=12mL, and reaction temperature=383K. Again, the acetal yield first increased gradually with increasing catalyst amount, reaching a peak value of 94.6% at a catalyst loading of 5wt%, then descended progressively when the amount of catalyst was further increased. It is anticipated that, the amount of active acid sites may be inadequate to catalyze the reaction with desirable conversion and acetal yield. In this case, a desirable amount of catalyst for efficient acetalization reaction was found to be ca. 5wt%. Further increasing the catalyst amount beyond 5wt% may provoke formation of undesirable side-products to spoil selectivity of acetal. Since water is inevitably formed during acetalization reaction, the reaction equilibrium may readily be driven to formation of acetal provided that water is being removed efficiently. Since cyclohexane was exploited as the water-carrying agent in the present study, the experimental results shown in Fig. 3d were obtained by carrying out the reaction with varied amounts of cyclohexane (6−18mL) while keeping other parameters constant, viz. EG/BzH=1.5mol/mol, amount of catalyst=5wt%, reaction time=2.0h, and reaction temperature=383K. Similar to the above cases, the acetal yield first increased with increasing amount of water-carrying agent to reach a maximum of 94.6% at 12mL cyclohexane. As the amount of cyclohexane continue to increase beyond 12mL, the acetal yield gradually decreased due to dilution of catalyst system, hence, lowering of acidity and catalytic activity. 3.4 Stability test Owing to their self-separation characteristics, the M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts are advantaged by their feasibility for catalyst separation and recycling. Since the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst exhibits the best catalytic performance for acetalization of BzH with EG, its durability and reusability were investigated. The test experiments were conducted under the optimized reaction variables obtained from RSM (vide infra). As shown in Fig. 4 , the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst was indeed found to be highly durable with only minor loss in catalytic activity after six consecutive experimental runs. It is noteworthy that, upon completion of each run, the catalyst was filtered and washed with diethyl ether and reused after drying. The acetal yield decreased marginally from 95.0% in the first cycle to 87.9% in the 6th cycle. Additional FT-IR measurements also revealed that the structural integrity of the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst remained practically unchanged; the characteristic absorption bands responsible for the Keggin PW anions of TPA were preserved in the regenerated catalyst (Fig. S5; SI). The slight decrease in catalytic activity during cyclic studies may be attributed to the loss of TPA during the regeneration treatment, as evidenced by elemental analysis by using ICP technique, which revealed that the content of P atom decreased from 0.98wt% of the fresh catalyst to 0.82wt% of the spent catalyst regenerated after the 6th run. In spite of this drawback, the above results indicate that the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 is indeed a robust catalyst with desirable durability and recyclability for acetalization reactions. 3.5 Process optimization and model fitting Response surface methodology (RSM) was employed to further investigate possible interactive effects between experimental variables and to optimize the process variables. The four independent process variables, namely EG/BzH molar ratio (x 1), reaction time (x 2), amount of catalyst (x 3), and amount of cyclohexane as the water-carrying agent (x 4) and their corresponding coded levels for the Box-Behnken experimental design used in the present study are depicted in Table 2. Accordingly, the experimental acetal yield obtained for the acetalization reaction over the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst under various variables and levels are summarized in Table 3 together with the response values predicted by the quadratic model equation: (8) Y = +94.58−0.88x 1 −0.30x 2 −0.75x 3 −0.71x 4 +0.98 x 1 x2 −0.45 x 1 x3 +1.30x 1 x4 +0.60x 2 x3 −0.47x 2 x 4 +0.40x 3 x 4 −2.30x 1 2 −1.81x 2 2 −1.42x 3 2 −1.38x 4 2 where Y represent the response of acetal yield, .x1 , x2 , x3 , and x4 denotes the coded values of the four independent test variables, as defined in Table 2. The quality of the multiple regression fitting of Eq. (8) may be assessed by the coefficient of determination (R2 ). As a result, a value of R 2 =0.9531 was achieved, indicating that the model was reliable and that a close match between the experimental and predicted values may be inferred. Moreover, the fitting quality of the quadratic model was further assessed by the standard analysis of variance (ANOVA) and the results are depicted in Table 4 . That the obtained model F-value (10.15) was much larger than its critical (tabulated) counterpart (F0.01,14,14 =3.70) and that a P-value less than 0.0001 at 1% confidence level, implying that the predicted model was indeed significant. Moreover, most of the obtained “Prob > F” values being less than 0.05 confirmed that some of the individual and interactive terms in the model equation, namely x1 , x3 , x4 , x1 2 , x2 2 , x3 2 , x4 2 , x1 × 2 , and x1 × 4 , were significant. A “Lack of fit” F-value of 1.78 also implied the “Lack of fit” is not significant relative to the pure error, and the model fitted to all data nicely. Whilst, the “Adeq Precision” (10.05), which represents the signal to noise ratio, was also greater than the desirable value (4.0). In addition, the coefficient of variation (CV) of 0.73% also demonstrated the prevailing adequate signal-to-noise ratio and reproducible measurements. Together, the above ANOVA results clearly indicate that the proposed model was highly reliable and that the experimental design was also highly reasonable for the prediction of acetal yield over the transition-metal incorporated organic-inorganic composite catalysts, especially for the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 sample. On the basis of results obtained from the 29 experimental sets (Table 3), the optimal process variable for acetalization reaction of BzH with EG over the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst may be derived as: EG/BzH ratio (x 1)=1.44mol/mol, reaction time (x 2)=1.92h, amount of catalyst (x 3)=4.69wt%, and amount of cyclohexane as water-carrying agent (x 4)=10.74mL at a reaction temperature of 383K. As a result, a benzaldehyde ethylene glycol acetal (BEGA) yield of 95.26% was predicted. To further verify these predicted results, four additional experiments were performed in parallel with somewhat simplified values of x 1 =1.45:1mol/mol, x 2 =2.0h, x 3 =4.7wt%, and x 4 =10.7mL, which resulted an experimental BEGA yield of 95.0%, in excellent agreement with the optimal experimental value (94.6%) listed in Table 1. 3.6 Kinetic modeling A kinetic study for acetalization of BzH with EG over the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst was also been made. The experiments were conducted using the optimized reaction conditions, namely, EG/BzH ratio=1.45:1mol/mol, reaction time=2h, amount of catalyst=4.7wt%, amount of cyclohexane=10.7mL, under varied reaction temperatures (353−393K). Typically, ca. 1mL of sample was withdrawn from the reaction mixture for analysis at different time intervals. As a result, variations of instantaneous concentrations of BzH (C A) and EG (C B) versus reaction time at various temperatures were analyzed to obtain the corresponding rate constant based on Eq. (4). Consequently, a correlation plot between the BEGA yield (Y) and reaction time may be obtained for each temperature based on Eq. (5). At a given temperature a linear dependent between acetal yield and reaction time was evident (Fig. 5 a), which verifies that the acetalization of BzH with EG was indeed a second-order reaction. Accordingly, an activation energy (Ea ) of 34.11kJ/mol and a pre-exponential factor (k0 ) of 325.2L/mol·s may be derived from the corresponding Arrhenius plot in Fig. 5b based on Eq. (6). Consequently, the rate equation for the acetalization reaction may readily be written as: r = − d C A d t = e 5.78 ( − 34.11 R T ) C A C B (9) It is noteworthy that the Ea value so obtained for the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst during acetalization of BzH with EG is much smaller compared to that observed for acetalization of formaldehyde with ethylene glycol over an Amberlyst-47 acidic ion exchange resin (55.4kJ/mol) [62] and for acetalization of glycerol and ethylaldehyde over an Amberlyst-15 catalyst (77.7kJ/mol) [63]. The above results obtained from kinetic study therefore provide strong supports to reveal that the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 composite is indeed a highly active and efficient catalyst for acetalization of benzaldehyde with glycol. These information relevant to the reaction process should be beneficial for future evaluation of M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts for potential industrial applications. 4 Conclusions A series of transition-metal (M) ion-exchanged M-MIMPS-TPA (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) catalysts were successfully synthesized by simply mixing inorganic tungstophosphoric acid (H3PW12O40; TPA) with organic methylimidazolium propyl sulfobetaine (MIMPS) zwitterionic ionic liquid along with a desirable amount of metal nitride precursors. The organic-inorganic composite catalysts so prepared were not only found to be feasible for heterogeneous/homogeneous catalysis but also possess unique self-separation property, catalyst stability, and exceptional high activity for catalytic reactions. Among them, Ni2+-exchanged TPA-based IL composites, namely Ni x [MIMPSH] y H(3−2x−y)PW12O40 (x =0−1.5, y =0−2), were found to show superior catalytic activities for acetalization of benzaldehyde with ethylene glycol, leading to a maximum acetal yield of 94.6% over the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst with excellent conversion and selectivity. An effect of Brønsted-Lewis acid synergy and low molecular transport resistance of the catalyst was found responsible for the high acetalization activity observed. These eco-friendly and robust catalysts with favorable properties for product separation and catalyst recycling, render practical cost-effective and versatile industrial applications for catalytic conversions of biomass. coredata.dc:description: A series of transition-metal (M=Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) ion-exchanged tungstophosphoric acid (H3PW12O40; TPA)-based ionic liquid (IL) catalysts, synthesized by incorporating metal and methylimidazolium propyl sulfobetaine (MIMPS) zwitterionic IL precursors onto TPA, were exploited for acetalization of benzaldehyde (BzH) with ethylene glycol (EG). These organic-inorganic, water-soluble M-MIMPS-TPA composite salts possess not only strong Brønsted and Lewis acidities but also exhibited unique self-separation property desirable for catalyst separation and recycling. The superior acetalization activities observed for these novel M-MIMPS-TPA catalysts are attributed to their strong acidity, Brønsted/Lewis acid synergy, and low mass transport resistance. Among them, the Ni[MIMPSH]PW12O40 catalyst showed extraordinary catalytic performance and durability with a benzaldehyde glycol acetal selectivity and yield of 99.0 and 94.6%, respectively, in excellent agreement with results from response surface methodology. Further kinetic study gave rise to an activation energy of 34.11kJ/mol for the acetalization reaction, surpassing most reported catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Transition-metal incorporated heteropolyacid-ionic liquid composite catalysts with tunable Brønsted/Lewis acidity for acetalization of benzaldehyde with ethylene glycol
